content: I posit that Obama SHOULD do nothing - diplomatically at least, and definitely not militarily. This is one thing that Bush did correctly. As another poster mentioned already, first and foremost there is nothing that he could do without drastic consequences for Seoul that is not already being done. With all of the sanctions imposed already, North Korea is a perfect pariah, with the options to do almost anything they want. Second, the pattern here is that the Norks throw a temper tantrum of some sort, and then we reward them with a cookie. Bush broke that pattern. He ignored them, and it was the Chinese that got them to sit down for 6-party talks. Then, the administration turns over, the Norks back out of talks and repeat the pattern, knowing that they have been rewarded for it in the past. Simple solution - don't give them what they want. Treat this as what it is, an act of frustration that, in the short term, has no effect on us and a huge effect on South Korea and China, who will ultimately solve the problem (with our backing). China has more at stake here than we do, considering the refugee disaster just waiting to spill over into their borders. The last thing they want is for North Korea to blow up, so they, having much more at stake than us, will step up and be the regional superpower they aspire to be. They have more leverage than we could ever dream of, and they WILL reign in the North Korean military if it comes down to it.

Treat this as what it is, an act of frustration that, in the short term, has no effect on us and a huge effect on South Korea and China, who will ultimately solve the problem (with our backing). China has more at stake here than we do, considering the refugee disaster just waiting to spill over into their borders. The last thing they want is for North Korea to blow up, so they, having much more at stake than us, will step up and be the regional superpower they aspire to be. They have more leverage than we could ever dream of, and they WILL reign in the North Korean military if it comes down to it.

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: who remembers the stern consequence speech that madam hillary made about nk and its various programs what are they?? stern consequences that is quote: Bush condemns North Korea's 'provocative' test By Steve Holland WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President George W. Bush, facing a new election-year foreign policy crisis, condemned North Korea's reported nuclear test on Monday and vowed the United States will respect security commitments in Asia. Speaking about 12 hours after the news broke of North Korea's nuclear test, Bush said he talked by phone with the leaders of China, South Korea, Japan and Russia and all agreed it was unacceptable and deserved an immediate response from the U.N. Security Council +http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/10/10/worldupdates/2006-10-09T211009Z_01_NOOTR_RTRJONC_0_-271471-2&sec=Worldupdates quote: July 5, 2006 · Calling North Korea's missile tests a provocative act, President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice pledge that the United States will rely on six-party talks to deal with the issue. Over the past 24 hours, Pyongyang has gotten the world's attention, as North Korea launched up to seven missiles into the Sea of Japan. One of the missiles was reportedly a long-range type that could potentially reach Alaska. +http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5536133 "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: quote: Originally posted by Bleah: China has more at stake here than we do, considering the refugee disaster just waiting to spill over into their borders. The last thing they want is for North Korea to blow up, so they, having much more at stake than us, will step up and be the regional superpower they aspire to be. They have more leverage than we could ever dream of, and they WILL reign in the North Korean military if it comes down to it. Absolutely correct! quote: China debates its bond with North Korea Reporting from Beijing -- When is it time to dump an old friend who insists on behaving badly? The debate is raging in China. North Korea's latest nuclear test raises the question of just how long the bonds forged between old communist allies will endure. The test was conducted barely 50 miles from the Chinese border. The ground rumbled in northeast China, and some schools were evacuated because of fears of an earthquake. "It was quite shocking. The location where they did this test was a lot closer to China than to where [North Korean leader] Kim Jong Il is living in Pyongyang," said Zhang Liangui, a Korea expert with Beijing's Central Party School, where Communist Party officials are trained. (....) Within the Chinese intelligentsia there is a deep divide over how to handle North Korea. The Global Times, a newspaper with close party ties, Tuesday published a survey of 20 of the country's top foreign policy experts. It found them split down the middle -- 10 arguing for tough sanctions against North Korea, 10 opposed. "Traditionally, China has been very friendly to North Korea, but now there is a feeling that the North Koreans are causing us too much trouble," Zhang said. (....) +http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-china-korea27-2009may27,0,4095573.story "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: quote: Originally posted by RBruce: What will the President do when NK drops a nuke in the unpopulated mountains of Alaska? Will we go to war or issue another UN declaration? What a silly question. What possible reason could North Korea, a state that is wholly dedicated to the survival of its ruling class AS a ruling class, have to do something stupid like that? The funny thing about international relations is that nations always have a logical (well, logical from their point of view anyway) reason for doing what they do. What logic would compel North Korea to commit state suicide? Their logic in this latest round of brinksmanship is clear. They are telling the west to back off while they settle succession (the Asian Elvis is about to leave the building), and they are hoping for more concessions from their neighbors....again. The fact that they get to show their potential buyers that their weapons actually work is a nice bonus. The only thing they really want above all else is to remain in power. They will not endanger that through anything but unintentional miscalculation of world response.

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: 05/29/09 another test for NK missile program.. test completed us response so far zero As Bleah said, the US response SHOULD be zero. GW Bush, and recent SK and Japanese leadership, have broken the cycle of throwing the Norks an appeasement cookie every time they rattle their saber. Plus, China does have a ton of leverage (they are just about single-handedly supporting what little economy the norks do have), and the LAST thing they (and Russia, point of fact) want is millions of refugees streaming over their border. NOBODY will tolerate the norks starting a shooting war, much less flinging a handful of nukes at their neighbors. Even the possible thrreat of the norks selling a nuke to AQ or to Iran to give to AQ...it's a nuke, not a homemade zipgun. Let's say a nork nuke does get put on the black market and then set off in NYC. It WILL get traced back to the country of origin, who WILL get treated just as if they had launched it themselves. Why haven't any of those missing nukes from the USSR been aquired by a terrorist group and then set off in NYC or Tel Aviv? I'll tell you why: because the Kremlin knows we would hold them responsible. When it all comes down to it, China will rein them in. China wants to be the regional superpower. They want their economy to keep rolling at 9%, which won't happen if the norks start a shooting war.

content: I posit that Obama SHOULD do nothing - diplomatically at least, and definitely not militarily. This is one thing that Bush did correctly. As another poster mentioned already, first and foremost there is nothing that he could do without drastic consequences for Seoul that is not already being done. With all of the sanctions imposed already, North Korea is a perfect pariah, with the options to do almost anything they want. Second, the pattern here is that the Norks throw a temper tantrum of some sort, and then we reward them with a cookie. Bush broke that pattern. He ignored them, and it was the Chinese that got them to sit down for 6-party talks. Then, the administration turns over, the Norks back out of talks and repeat the pattern, knowing that they have been rewarded for it in the past. Simple solution - don't give them what they want. Treat this as what it is, an act of frustration that, in the short term, has no effect on us and a huge effect on South Korea and China, who will ultimately solve the problem (with our backing). China has more at stake here than we do, considering the refugee disaster just waiting to spill over into their borders. The last thing they want is for North Korea to blow up, so they, having much more at stake than us, will step up and be the regional superpower they aspire to be. They have more leverage than we could ever dream of, and they WILL reign in the North Korean military if it comes down to it.

They have more leverage than we could ever dream of, and they WILL reign in the North Korean military if it comes down to it.

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: who remembers the stern consequence speech that madam hillary made about nk and its various programs what are they?? stern consequences that is quote: Bush condemns North Korea's 'provocative' test By Steve Holland WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President George W. Bush, facing a new election-year foreign policy crisis, condemned North Korea's reported nuclear test on Monday and vowed the United States will respect security commitments in Asia. Speaking about 12 hours after the news broke of North Korea's nuclear test, Bush said he talked by phone with the leaders of China, South Korea, Japan and Russia and all agreed it was unacceptable and deserved an immediate response from the U.N. Security Council +http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/10/10/worldupdates/2006-10-09T211009Z_01_NOOTR_RTRJONC_0_-271471-2&sec=Worldupdates quote: July 5, 2006 · Calling North Korea's missile tests a provocative act, President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice pledge that the United States will rely on six-party talks to deal with the issue. Over the past 24 hours, Pyongyang has gotten the world's attention, as North Korea launched up to seven missiles into the Sea of Japan. One of the missiles was reportedly a long-range type that could potentially reach Alaska. +http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5536133 "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: quote: Originally posted by psychoABN: Well, one nuke test and three missile tests in two days. I think someone's being tested..... Biden was right when he stated Obama would be tested! Now, let's see just how wise the President is? I'd encourgae the Norks to keep sending missles into nowhere. Every one used is less they can stockpile. Let's face it they already have nuclear capability. There is only one way to stop them and that is through assured annihilation if they should ever fire one at a friendly country. Right now we can reach them, but they cannot reach us. We need to place a missle defense system all around them. Get them into an arms race where they go broke, just like Russia did. Let their government collapse and hopefully calmer heads will take over. They are very near economic collapse now, it wouldn't tke much to push them over the edge.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bleah: China has more at stake here than we do, considering the refugee disaster just waiting to spill over into their borders. The last thing they want is for North Korea to blow up, so they, having much more at stake than us, will step up and be the regional superpower they aspire to be. They have more leverage than we could ever dream of, and they WILL reign in the North Korean military if it comes down to it. Absolutely correct! quote: China debates its bond with North Korea Reporting from Beijing -- When is it time to dump an old friend who insists on behaving badly? The debate is raging in China. North Korea's latest nuclear test raises the question of just how long the bonds forged between old communist allies will endure. The test was conducted barely 50 miles from the Chinese border. The ground rumbled in northeast China, and some schools were evacuated because of fears of an earthquake. "It was quite shocking. The location where they did this test was a lot closer to China than to where [North Korean leader] Kim Jong Il is living in Pyongyang," said Zhang Liangui, a Korea expert with Beijing's Central Party School, where Communist Party officials are trained. (....) Within the Chinese intelligentsia there is a deep divide over how to handle North Korea. The Global Times, a newspaper with close party ties, Tuesday published a survey of 20 of the country's top foreign policy experts. It found them split down the middle -- 10 arguing for tough sanctions against North Korea, 10 opposed. "Traditionally, China has been very friendly to North Korea, but now there is a feeling that the North Koreans are causing us too much trouble," Zhang said. (....) +http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-china-korea27-2009may27,0,4095573.story "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: quote: Originally posted by RBruce: What will the President do when NK drops a nuke in the unpopulated mountains of Alaska? Will we go to war or issue another UN declaration? What a silly question. What possible reason could North Korea, a state that is wholly dedicated to the survival of its ruling class AS a ruling class, have to do something stupid like that? The funny thing about international relations is that nations always have a logical (well, logical from their point of view anyway) reason for doing what they do. What logic would compel North Korea to commit state suicide? Their logic in this latest round of brinksmanship is clear. They are telling the west to back off while they settle succession (the Asian Elvis is about to leave the building), and they are hoping for more concessions from their neighbors....again. The fact that they get to show their potential buyers that their weapons actually work is a nice bonus. The only thing they really want above all else is to remain in power. They will not endanger that through anything but unintentional miscalculation of world response.

content: ALL Where are the Carriers? The Japan Sea has to be busy these days. Radiation flyovers, monitoring launch pads, setting up small boys to do inspection duty on incoming ships. Whew. Busy days at what we do best. Old NK, playing the bad guy role to the hilt. Expect him to rattle sabers till he gets a pay off, just like old Bill C. did in 94. OBNA knows the drill, not to worry. The NK folks are just playing according to well established Soviet Rules of Engagement. Scream, yell, holler and rattle whatever weapon you happen to possess. Scare the Capiltalists, then wait for the food trucks to pacify... Folks, NK leaders know full well, if there is a SERIOUS attempt to load a nuk on one the oft times missfired missles NK has, the launch pad will dissolve in smoke. A 20 k altitude Boeing Predator with a Hell Fire can do enough damage to a launch pad to set back thier efforts by years. Not possible? Ask the Taliban leaders who sat down to lunch and never got up. end

content: quote: Originally posted by Ira1945: 05/29/09 another test for NK missile program.. test completed us response so far zero As Bleah said, the US response SHOULD be zero. GW Bush, and recent SK and Japanese leadership, have broken the cycle of throwing the Norks an appeasement cookie every time they rattle their saber. Plus, China does have a ton of leverage (they are just about single-handedly supporting what little economy the norks do have), and the LAST thing they (and Russia, point of fact) want is millions of refugees streaming over their border. NOBODY will tolerate the norks starting a shooting war, much less flinging a handful of nukes at their neighbors. Even the possible thrreat of the norks selling a nuke to AQ or to Iran to give to AQ...it's a nuke, not a homemade zipgun. Let's say a nork nuke does get put on the black market and then set off in NYC. It WILL get traced back to the country of origin, who WILL get treated just as if they had launched it themselves. Why haven't any of those missing nukes from the USSR been aquired by a terrorist group and then set off in NYC or Tel Aviv? I'll tell you why: because the Kremlin knows we would hold them responsible. When it all comes down to it, China will rein them in. China wants to be the regional superpower. They want their economy to keep rolling at 9%, which won't happen if the norks start a shooting war.
